title: Full Corpus Comparison: LLM-as-Judge vs Embedding Divergence

llm_judge_summary.methodology: LLM-as-Judge analysis using Claude Opus 4.5 evaluating philosophical_fidelity, tonal_preservation, and interpretive_liberty across 5 translators

1_Kaufmann.profile: Scholarly standard. Best philosophical precision. Combines fidelity with readability. Excellent handling of technical German philosophical terms. Ranked first in 135 aphorisms.

2_Hollingdale.profile: Most literal translator. Second highest top-ranking count (117). Excellent structural fidelity to German. Highest tonal preservation score. Best choice for literal accuracy.

3_Faber.profile: Moderately interpretive translator. Modern accessibility prioritized. Some philosophical terms weakened (e.g., 'trips over' vs 'attacks' for aggressive German verbs).

4_Norman.profile: Contemporary scholarly voice. Some corpus alignment issues detected in early aphorisms. Strong when text is complete.

5_Zimmern.profile: Historical first translation (1906). Victorian language. Some corpus corruption. Variable quality across aphorisms.

embedding_comparison.methodology: paraphrase-multilingual-MiniLM-L12-v2 embeddings, divergence = 1 - mean_cosine_similarity across translator pairs
embedding_comparison.key_finding: Embedding divergence is a POOR predictor of philosophical translation quality differences

case_1_high_embedding_low_llm.llm_verdict: All translators score 8-9 on philosophical fidelity. High embedding divergence driven by text length variation, not philosophical divergence.

case_2_low_embedding_high_llm.llm_finding: Norman's 'barbaric to love one thing alone' expands German structure significantly. Kaufmann missing from corpus. Philosophical interpretation varies despite lexical similarity.

case_3_grammatical_invisible.finding: Embeddings cluster 'reverence for itself' (noun) and 'reveres itself' (verb) closely despite different philosophical implications. Grammatical-philosophical nuance invisible to vector space.

synthesis.primary_insight: Embedding similarity measures lexical overlap, not philosophical fidelity. High embedding similarity does NOT mean philosophical equivalence.
synthesis.recommendation: Use embeddings for detecting OCR errors and corpus anomalies. Use LLM-as-Judge for translation quality assessment.
what_embeddings_miss: Grammatical distinctions (noun vs verb, singular vs plural)
Translator interpretive choices that preserve semantic similarity

corpus_quality_issues_identified.Kaufmann_missing: Several aphorisms in explorer_data show Kaufmann as null

Wille_zur_Macht.issue: Some translators add article ('THE will to power') changing philosophical claim structure

Uebermensch.issue: Various renderings: overman, superman, higher man

Heerde.issue: Consistently rendered but surrounding critique varies
